item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
I survived week 2!! It's been a tough week as we've been given the challenge to build the battleships game from scratch. Before last week, I've never even played battleships despite having heard of the game many times! I downloaded the game on my phone to find out what this battle is all about.

The real battle of course of was actually building it! The course material was designed to make us think, research and decide how we want to build the most basic game first e.g. with one ship and one player and then slowly scale from there. This is part of the process of designing the minimum viable product however while that was useful, we did have to think about how our program can be extended to allow for multiple ships and two players. It may be a simple game but building something like this requires you to think logically about the various scenarios of the game.

One week later, I'm just really grateful that those ships are static! Throughout building this game, we are starting to get to know, understand and apply the SOLID principles of Object Oriented Design, all in a test-driven way of course. We've had plenty of research projects on various SOLID topics. SOLID (stands for Single responsibility, Open-closed, Liskov substitution, Interface segregation and Dependency inversion) sets out the five principles of object oriented programming and design and is what we follow at Makers to ensure our code easy to maintain and extend. This week we've really focused on Single responsibility (one class should have only one job) and Dependency inversion.

We've continue to pair-program everyday and it's been very helpful. As we switch partners everyday, we are working with another set of code that may have been modelled differently. We always have to work with the code that's less developed so we can build this code back up, which helps to consolidate our learning and ensure we can explain our code to one another.

I've also had plenty of fun doing yoga, playing badminton and partying with fellow makers on Friday. See, life as a coder isn't all about being bound to the desk!

item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
Blocks, procs and lambdas are ways we can group code that we wish to run.

A block is a function and usually represented in curly braces. It is NOT an object and needs to be called by a method For example:

 { puts "Print me" } => Syntax Error

 [1,2,3].each { |x| puts x*2 }
 => 2
    4
    6

A proc is a reusable block saved as an object so that can be passed into other methods. It is created using Proc.new {} and is an instance of the Proc class. Below is the same example but using a proc and passing it into the each method. 

 p = Proc.new { |x| puts x*2 }
 [1,2,3].each(&p)    => '&' tells ruby to turn the proc into a block 
 2
 4
 6

 p.class 
 => Proc             => A proc is an instance of the Proc class

Another example:

 proc = Proc.new { puts "Hello World" }
 proc.call
 "Hello World"

Unlike blocks, multiple procs can be passed in as arguments. It will discard any additional proc arguments not given e.g. proc3 in the example below.

 def multiple_procs(proc1, proc2, proc3)
   proc1.call
   proc2.call
 end

 a = Proc.new { puts "First proc" }
 b = Proc.new { puts "Second proc" }

 multiple_procs(a,b)
 "First proc"
 "Second proc"

A lambda is a Proc object but checks the number of arguments and will throw an error if the exact number of arguments is not given. Examples below:

lam = lambda { |x| puts x*2 }
lam.call(2)
4
lam.call(2,4) => Argument Error: wrong number of arguments (2 for 1)

The other difference between procs and lambdas is they treat the 'return' keyword differently. A ‘return’ inside of a lambda triggers the code right outside of the lambda code. 

def lambda_test
  lam = lambda { return }
  lam.call
  puts "Print me"
end

lambda_test
"Print me"

A ‘return’ inside of a proc triggers the code outside of the method where the proc is being executed. 

def proc_test
  proc = Proc.new { return }
  proc.call
  puts "Hello world"
end

proc_test                 # calling proc_test prints nothing

item.title: Ruby Gems
item.description: Gems are libraries made up out of Ruby code and packaged up to run on any platform that Ruby runs on. Each gem has a name, version and contains code, documentation and gemspec. The gem can be easily downloaded and installed on your computer and will be available for you
item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
Gems are libraries made up out of Ruby code and packaged up to run on any platform that Ruby runs on. Each gem has a name, version and contains code, documentation and gemspec. The gem can be easily downloaded and installed on your computer and will be available for you to use in every program you write. Rubygems.org is the most popular repository of “gems” for the Ruby language.

An example of a Ruby gem is Byebug which allows you to see what is going on inside a Ruby program while it executes and offers many of the traditional debugging features such as:

  • Stepping - running your program one line at a time.
  • Breaking - pausing the program at some event or specified instruction, to examine the current state.
  • Evaluating: Basic read–eval–print loop (REPL) functionality
  • Tracking: Keeping track of the different values of your variables or the different lines executed by your program.

The below example shows you how to use byebug in code. Here's method that takes a string and returns an array whose keys are all the downcased words in the string, and values are number of times these words were seen. To use the byebug gem, you will need to require it at the beginning of the method. You can then insert 'byebug' where you want to track your code.

require 'byebug'

def word_count(string)
  separate_words = string.downcase.split
  words_counted = Hash.new(0)
  separate_words.each { |word| 
    words_counted.store(word, words_counted[word] + 1) }
  words_counted
  byebug
end

word_count "The dog and the cat"

Run this code in Terminal and you can see what each line of code is returning. 

[12, 21] in 3_hashes.rb
  12: def word_count(string)
  13:   separate_words = string.downcase.split
  14:   words_counted = Hash.new(0)
  15:   separate_words.each { |word| 
        words_counted.store(word,   words_counted[word] + 1) }
  16:   words_counted
  17:   byebug 
  => 18: end
  19: 
  20: word_count "The dog and the cat"
  21: 
  (byebug) separate_words
    ["the", "dog", "and", "the", "cat"]
  (byebug) words_counted = Hash.new(0)
    {}
  (byebug) separate_words.each { |word| 
  words_counted.store(word, words_counted[word] + 1) }
    ["the", "dog", "and", "the", "cat"]
  (byebug) words_counted
    {"the"=>2, "dog"=>1, "and"=>1, "cat"=>1}

Dangers of Ruby gems

Some of the dangers of using gems is you are essentially trusting that the gem works as well as the it's developer. Asides from well-known and trusted developers, you don't essentially know who they are. As gems can run code on install, the risk is that gems can steal the unencrypted Rubygems.org credentials which can then be used to modify the compromised user's gems and spread malicious code.

It is also impossible to notify a gem user of compromised gems. When a gem developer’s credentials are compromised it is hard to notify anyone who uses any of the gems published by the developer of the situation.

item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
What is the difference between Inheritance and Composition in Object-oriented programming? Why might using Composition be a better way to go?

Inheritance

Inheritance is used when one class wishes to get all its features from a parent class. Syntactically, this is achieved using "<". In Ruby, each class can only inherit once from another class. The example below shows a Cat class and the breed, Persian class inheriting form the cat class and getting it's initialization and make_noise methods. While the Persian class has inherited the Cat class, it can also make additional changes such as adding colour when it gets instantiated in addition to having four legs. 

class Cat
  def initialize
    @legs = 4
  end

  def make_noise
    "Meow!"
  end
end

class Persian < Cat
 def initialize(color)
   @color = black
   super()
end

cat = Cat.new
persian = Persian.new

cat.make_noise
=> "Meow!"
persian.make_noise
=> "Meow!"

The downside of using inheritance is that it violates the encapsulation principle. You are essentially bonding one class to another so it is dependent on the parent class and it's behaviours. These behaviours may change in the future and may not be relevant to the class that is inheriting from it. It can also be hard to test classes that reuse code from the parent class.

Composition

While inheritance can be useful, you can achieve the same thing by using other classes and modules. They package of methods that can be used by other classes. The main difference between classes and modules is that modules can't be instantiated but can be included easily in other classes to be used. Below is an example of using classes for the battleships game. The player is able to create a board and access board's method receive_ship. 

 require_relative 'board'

 class Board
   attr_reader :ship_array

   def initialize
     @ship_array = []
    end

   def receive_ship(ship)
     ship_array << ship
   end
 end


 class Player
   attr_reader :board

   def initialize
     @board = Board.new
   end

   def place(ship)
     board.receive_ship(ship)
   end
 end

item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
The coding doesn't stop just because we've hit the weekend. Every Friday at 5pm, we get a weekend challenge that aims to test our knowledge on the week's learnings. The last weekend, I built a program that will control the flow of planes at an airport. The features include:

  • it allows pilots to land planes and take off from the airport
  • it allows air traffic controller to prevent planes from landing when it's full
  • when the weather is stormy, it allows the air traffic controller to prevent planes from landing or taking off.

During the week, we spend a lot of time exploring the week's challenge and trying out different solutions. The weekend actually gives me the space to absorb the learnings and put it into practice on my own. I started by thinking about the problem and the user stories and how to organise my classes. It can be tricky not to overthink the problem and making it harder for yourself. Always start with the Minimum Viable Product (MVP) and listing what the objects are and their responsibilities. You can then extend it from there.

The other interesting thing was testing my weather method which uses an in-built ruby method rand. It was the only test that wasn't passing Coveralls- a platform that checks how much of your code is covered by your tests. I wasn't sure how to test random itself. The tricky thing with testing the random method is that in order to test if it's working properly, you have to know what to expect, and that's not possible if the random number is generated every time the test is run.

I asked my cohort buddy Yana for some advice and she taught me how to test random using srand which lets you pick the seed number so you can generate a sequence of numbers that seems random, but is actually predictable. Here is an example:

First you seed the number which just gives you a list of random numbers

srand(1234)
=> 244615853692375567264193332865866353245

Then the next rand method you use will use this seed number and generate a seeded sequence. So that when you use the rand on a number, it will give you the same number when you use it. 

rand
=> 0.1915194503788923
rand
=> 0.6221087710398319
rand(10)
=> 4
rand(400)
=> 152

And to show that you can run the same sequence again... 

rand(1234)
=> 1234
rand
=> 0.1915194503788923
rand
=> 0.6221087710398319
rand(10)
=> 4
rand(400)
=> 152

The seed you set works only once, so the next time you call rand, it will not use your specified seed number.

rand(1234)
=> 1234
rand
=> 0.1915194503788923
rand
=> 0.6221087710398319
rand(10)
=> 4
rand(400)
=> 152
rand(400)
=> 144

Anyway that's my attempt at explaining srand!

On Monday, one of the Senior cohort members conducted a code review with us and gave us tips on how we can improve our Airport program. Our coaches will also complete this. It was really helpful to discuss the code in detail and look for opportunities to refactor our code.

This week we are building the battleships game so I will post a recap later in the week!

item.title: SOLID: Dependency Inversion
item.description:
Describe the SOLID principle of dependency inversion, by giving an example of dependency injection with a module and a class. How does DI improve the reusability of code?

The last SOLID principle is called dependency inversion and it refers to a specific form of decoupling software modules. It has two
item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
Describe the SOLID principle of dependency inversion, by giving an example of dependency injection with a module and a class. How does DI improve the reusability of code?

The last SOLID principle is called dependency inversion and it refers to a specific form of decoupling software modules. It has two parts:

  • High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules. Both should depend on abstractions. If high-level modules are dependent on the details of the lower-level modules, and if these details change, then you will have to change the high-level modules as well.

  • Abstractions should not depend upon details. Details should depend upon abstractions. Abstraction is a mechanism and practice to reduce and factor out details so that one can focus on a few concepts at a time.

Here is an example without abstracting:

Suppose we have a Dog class that has a method called speak and another class named Wolf that has a bark method. The dog class calls on it's speak method instantiates a new Wolf and calls on it's bark method. But what if it's a different species that makes a different noise?

class Animal
   def speak
     Dog.new.noise
   end
end

class Dog
  def noise
    puts 'Bark!'
  end
end

This can be refactored using abstractions by:

class Animal
   def speak(species)
     species.noise
   end
end

class Wolf
  def noise
    puts 'Howl!'
  end
end

class Dog
  def noise
   puts 'Bark!'
  end
end

This approach is better because we won't need to change the code of the Animal class (high-level class) if we have a different species that "speak" differently. We can use the speak method inside the Animal class by passing an instance of a new breed as an argument. 

animal = Animal.new
animal.speak(Wolf.new)
Howl!
animal.speak(Dog.new)
Bark!

After Day 1, it was straight down to the business of learning Test Driven Development and Object Oriented Design which is
item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
First week at Makers has come to an end and it did not disappoint. It was absolutely jam-packed with learning opportunities and social activities. I had a fabulous time.

After Day 1, it was straight down to the business of learning Test Driven Development and Object Oriented Design which is all about modelling objects and how they will send messages to each other. Everything we code from now on will be tested. It is the best way to ensure our code works and is clean, concise and insured! It is also the best industry practice and I can understand why.

This has been our daily routine so far:

  • Stand-up at 9am sharp
  • Pair-program with a different partner everyday on our project
  • Lunch
  • Optional meditation class at 2pm
  • Afternoon stand-up
  • Pair-program again until late

I love it so far and you get into the rhythm of this pretty quickly. There are also other activities like ping-pong and yoga on selected days. It helps us to clear our heads and not be desk-bound all day. Looking after our mental health is also very important so we have energy and focus to keep going.

This week's project: Boris Bikes

This week's project was to write a program for a bike hire system. Bikes are located at docking stations throughout the city and anyone can hire them for a small fee. Our system will allow bikes to be released, returned and ensure any reported broken bikes can not be released. After all we want happy and satisfied customers.


Boris Bikes in Melbourne

The very first thing we do is understand the users stories which is important. User stories helps us identify objects and their responsibilities. We need to decide what are their behaviours and who do they need to send messages to in order for the system to work. What amazes me is how fun this is. We are actually modelling real life things, processes and situations. All the pre-course work provides a good foundation to start applying our Ruby methods in this way. It's like that was the toolbox and they are what we need to build our program.

Was the project hard? Yes, but not impossible. The rspec testing was all new to us as well as the rspec syntax but this is just part of the journey and we are in this playground so we can experiment and learn. Pair-programming was also great. It's like like ping-pong and having a buddy to bounce with. I've pair-programmed with three partners this week and I've learnt so much from each of them. Much love to Yana, Harry and Harriet. You guys rock my world! Yana is from Moscow and I am just in love with her accent. Her english is fantastic and she very thorough, methodical and also a quick thinker. Harry is just a ball of fun to analyse problems with. He will suddenly come up with an idea and BOOM, it works like magic. Harriet is also amazing and we just never quit at the problem. It's like we are on the battlefield and we just soldier through. I'm so thankful they are in this cohort! You guys rocked my world this week!

The other thing I want to mention is our stand-ups. We are split into different groups and twice a day, the group meets up. This is where we get the opportunity to ask questions on anything we don't understand. Our group coach then goes through it all with us in detail. It's a fantastic session and the coaches are just wonderful. They are able to explain concepts in a way that's easy to digest. I had Samm this week and I am in awe of the way he explains things. Not only is he extremely knowledgable but he is also very patient and approachable. Lucky us!

In other news, there's been a lot of pub nights. At this rate, I'm seriously going to get a beer gut. I think I need to just go on Fridays but even as I type this, I'm not confident that it will happen. :)

There are around 34 people in the cohort, the biggest ever at Makers and we all played this name game where that allowed us all to remember EVERYONE'S name. It was brilliant and I won't spoil it for anyone who is thinking about joining Makers (just do it! :D).

Makers also offers meditation everyday at 2pm (with Chief Joy Officer) and yoga on Mondays and Thursdays. Doctor Joy (aka Dana) is responsible for our happiness (and probably sanity!) and is literally a walking sunshine. She literally beams and oozes joy. Yep, I certainly want to get some of that joyfulness to keep me going.

We finished early and ended up at the local pub. I have a feeling this is going to be a regular pitstop! It was a great day and I know the hard work starts tomorrow. Bring it on.

I've been doing Codewars and reading the The Well-Grounded Rubyist by David A. Black. So far, it's been a good resource to help you to understand
item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
We are onto the last week of the pre-course before bootcamp starts so last chance to learn as much as possible before course starts!

I've been doing Codewars and reading the The Well-Grounded Rubyist by David A. Black. So far, it's been a good resource to help you to understand the fundamentals of the Ruby language and has plenty of examples with line-by-line explanations. There are still a few elements in there that I scratch my head at particularly the last couple of chapters! Maybe in time with more practice, I will understand it more?! I hope!

In between reading and doing Codewars, I've been practicing Ruby Zen by doing Ruby Koans. At first, I was like huh? what is this path to enlightenment that I've embarked on? The format was very different and it's essentially a a list of exercises that walks you through the Ruby language, its syntax and common function BUT it asks you fix code (filling in the missing elements) in order for it to work. It's good to switch different modes of thinking to test your understanding.

We were also asked to look at TDD (Test Driven Development aka Behaviour Driven Development) using a tool called rspec. From what I understand so far, it's an important part of the agile development process and involves coding, testing and refactoring your code. The process of TDD is to write the test (before you write any code), watch it fail and then write the simplest amount of code in order for the program to work. I can't wait to get to know TDD better when the course starts. The last month has absolutely gone by in a blink and no more late mornings!

It's time to go back to school. I hope I survive the next 12 weeks!

item.title: TDD and Red Green Refactor
item.description: TDD, also known as Test Driven Development is an important part of agile development. In a nutshell, it is about writing tests before any code, making that it sure it fails, then the writing the minimal and simplest code to make it pass, and refactoring the code at the very
item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
TDD, also known as Test Driven Development is an important part of agile development. In a nutshell, it is about writing tests before any code, making that it sure it fails, then the writing the minimal and simplest code to make it pass, and refactoring the code at the very end. This process can be explained using a cycle called Red Green Refactor, see diagram below.

There are two key tests involved - Feature Tests and Unit Tests.

Feature Tests tests one specific functionality e.g. such as a behaviour of a program.

Unit Tests tests the capability of the individual objects in a program isolated from all other objects.

A Feature Test is conducted prior to the Unit test.

What is red?

Red means watching a test (either feature or unit test) fail. We want the test to first fail because it confirms the validity of the test itself.

The first thing we do is perform a feature test and this involves writing a test for the code we wish we had. This will of course fail as we haven't written any code but this is good news! It means we can write the unit test for the components that make up this feature. Sounds weird, but we also want this to fail too! And this is for the same reasons as failing the feature test because it ensures the validity of the unit test. There may be multiple unit tests for each feature test.

Once both tests have failed in the expected way (the right errors), we can begin writing code that will pass both these tests.

What is green?

Green means watching your test PASS!! Awesome. The first thing we do is writing the minimal amount of code to pass our unit test. This ensures our code stays clean and concise. Once we've passed the unit test, we refactor the code relating to our unit. We run the test again to double check our refactored code passes.

The next step is to then write code to pass the feature test, adopting the same approach as the unit test above. Once again, we refactor and test at the end.

Final thoughts...

Once we've completed these steps, we have completed our program in a test-driven way. If we have done this correctly, we should have 100% coverage for our program and also the minimal amount of code possible.

item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
This week is all about practicing Ruby and finishing up our Chris Pine and Ruby Kickstart exercises. I switched up between the two just because I struggle with Mr. Pine especially when you've been hit with a cold...I mean why am I sick in summer??? But cold or not, I've soldiered on!

I've been addicted to doing Codewars which provides code challenges in a variety of different program languages to help improve your skill and technique. The more problems you solve, the more "honors" you earn and higher you rank up in the ladder of many codewar competitors. It's great fun and the problems get really tough. There are also some extremely creative and smart solutions. When you spent hours coming up with your code to a codewar problem (aka "kata") and only realise there were others that wrote them in one line, you get stumped and amazed! But while I think code needs to be clear and concise, it's also important to write code that's can be easily read and understood. I think this makes it easier for others to work with your code and build upon it or change it if needed. I try to break the problems down into chucks first and then refactor afterwards. That's another new word for me- refactoring. This is the process of when improving the code without changing what it's intended to do. So many new things to learn and I think I'm only scratching the surface at the moment.

Some of us in the September class also met up at Makers Academy to do some pair-programming. It was a great afternoon as I got the feel of what it's like to code and solve problems together as well as getting to know the Makers Academy space. We'll be doing a lot more of pair-programming so I'm looking forward to learning from others and sharing my knowledge. I also met up with my mentor who gave some tips about the course and we also worked on a Codewar problem together. While in the middle of this, a loud "GONG" sound went off and everyone on the floor cheered. I seriously thought it was beer time but it actually meant someone has landed a job! I like how Makers is so focused on preparing us to be job-ready and it is possible to get work if you do the work!

item.title: Pre-course Week 2: Getting Git
item.description:
Week two of the Makers Pre-course was all about learning Git and Github. I remember just a few weeks ago, I was looking at Github and thinking I don't get what this is about and how to use it!

After going through Maker's online learning and git immersion exercises, I
item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
Week two of the Makers Pre-course was all about learning Git and Github. I remember just a few weeks ago, I was looking at Github and thinking I don't get what this is about and how to use it!

After going through Maker's online learning and git immersion exercises, I am now adding, committing, pushing, pulling, cloning, and forking like never before. I can now see why keeping a local repository and a remote repository is so important when you are working and collaborating with others on projects. No doubt when the course starts, I'm sure we will be using both of these every day to track our work.

It's important not to get confused between Git and Github. They are different. Git is an open source version control system that allows you manage projects and keep track of it's changes on your computer. Github is a Git repository hosting service that allows you keep a copy of your code online so you can work and collaborate with others. Github isn't the only Git repo service available (e.g. Bitbucket) but it's a pretty damn good one from what I've seen and used so far.

Asides from Git and Github, I've been doing Josh Cheek's Ruby Kickstart and Chris Pine's Learn to Program. I find Chris Pine harder to understand but it's a good workout on my brain. There's so much to cover so I better get back to it!

item.dc:creator: Lucy Fang
item.content:encoded:
...for Lucy. That's me. I'm an Aussie traveller who decided to give up the comfortable Melbournian life for the hustle and bustle of London. Moving countries was certainly not easy but I think learning to code is even more of a challenge and this blog is about how I'm learning to be a developer with the help of Makers Academy!

Why do I want to code?

Having worked in the marketing and communications area for over a decade, I was always in awe of the brilliant technicians who can create, build, and make amazing websites and applications. While I found managing various projects was a great experience, I never felt completely satisfied with sitting on the bench. I always envied their technical skills and wished "I could do that!". So it was time to stop wishing, wondering and self-doubting, and give myself a chance to learn. I started self-learning online after work and found that I actually enjoyed coming home to code rather than work! That's a sure sign that you actually love what you are learning! I decided that even if I wasn't any good, there would be no regrets and I won't be left wondering what could have been! Besides, "you gotta risk it to get the biscuit". I can't remember who said that.

So here begins my journey to learn to code with Makers Academy. And why Makers? There's so many ways to learn and you've got to pick the one that's right for you. I looked into all options including learning on my own, online courses or bootcamps like Makers. I chose Makers because of their curriculum, supportive teachers and open learning environment. I also wanted to meet new people, learn from others and have that face-to-face contact. I was absolutely thrilled when I got accepted. Their application process consisted of an application submission and follow-up interview. All I can say is do the homework they tell you and ask lots of questions to make sure this is the course for you.

Pre-course Week 1 so far...

The bootcamp at Makers is 12 weeks and there's one month pre-course. The pre-course is important to help prep us for the bootcamp so there's heaps to do. We are given exercises and challenges to do every week and week 1 is all about the command line! I never realised how powerful and useful the command line is! I feel like everything is at my fingertips (pause for a Mr. Burns moment) and that gives me much satisfaction! I will sure be using it a lot more.
